title: 111_hr4897
content: The Act may be cited as the "Drivers Accelerated Interest Deductibility Act of 2010" or the "Drivers AID Act". Congress acknowledges the importance of a strong automotive industry for the economic health of the United States, highlighting the historical significance of automotive sales in retail spending. The period from June 2006 to May 2008 saw fluctuations in automotive sales, with rates above the indicator of a robust industry. The automotive industry has seen a decline in sales, with rates below the robust indicator of 13,000,000 units annually. Despite this, new vehicle dealers contribute significantly to the national economy, with total sales in 2008 reaching $576 billion. In 2008, new-vehicle dealerships in the United States had total sales of $576 billion, employing 1,057,500 people with an average annual salary of $48,963. This industry plays a crucial role in supporting the national economy and generating substantial tax revenue for state and local governments. The network is crucial for the success of automobile manufacturers, especially in challenging economic times, as it supports the new-vehicle dealer industry and benefits the national economy. Reducing the cost of capital for purchasing new vehicles can boost consumer confidence and incentivize purchases, strengthening the automotive manufacturing industry and the economy. Interest payments on automobile loans were deductible for Federal income tax for 73 years. The deduction for nonmortgage interest payments, including automobile loan debt, was available for Federal income tax purposes for 73 years until Congress eliminated it in 1986 with the Tax Reform Act. The deduction for interest on indebtedness incurred to acquire a passenger car or light truck was eliminated in 1986 with the Tax Reform Act. The Tax Reform Act of 1986 eliminated the deduction for interest on indebtedness to acquire a passenger car or light truck. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code now allows for a qualified vehicle interest deduction if the national unemployment rate is not less than 7 percent in the preceding quarter. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow for a qualified vehicle interest deduction, limited to $5,000, for interest properly chargeable on indebtedness incurred in acquiring a qualified vehicle. The qualified vehicle interest deduction is limited to $5,000 for interest on indebtedness properly allocable to a 36-month period. A qualified vehicle is a motor vehicle acquired for use by the taxpayer, with the original use commencing with the taxpayer. A qualified vehicle is a motor vehicle acquired for personal use by the taxpayer, meeting specific criteria such as being made by a manufacturer and treated as a motor vehicle under the Clean Air Act. A qualified vehicle is a motor vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating of 6,000 pounds or less, designed for use on public streets, roads, and highways with at least 4 wheels. A qualified vehicle is a motor vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating of 6,000 pounds or less, designed for use on public streets, roads, and highways with at least 4 wheels. The terms 'automobile', 'passenger automobile', 'light truck', and 'manufacturer' are defined by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency for purposes of the Clean Air Act. The average national unemployment rate for a calendar quarter is determined by the national unemployment rate. The amendment allows for a deduction in adjusted gross income for qualified vehicle interest under section 163(h)(5) of the Internal Revenue Code. The effective date for these changes is January 1, 2008.
